thread.title: Salary gap driving English NRL invasion
thread.title_full: Salary gap driving English NRL invasion

title: Salary gap driving English NRL invasion
text:
Why more England players are set to test themselves in the NRL, according to Elliott Whitehead  49pm @johndean_ Source: FOX SPORTS ENGLISH stars testing themselves in the NRL is nothing new but Canberra’s star import Elliott Whitehead expects the trickle to turn into an invasion as the salary gap begins to make the Super League uncompetitive. 
Whitehead says a number of his former teammates have told him of their aspirations to relocate to Australia and it’s not just proving themselves in the best competition in the world that’s driving the movement. 
The Super League salary cap sits at £1.8 million (just under AU$3.0m), well below that of the NRL’s which is expected to reach as high as $10 million in 2018. 
Whitehead, who joined the Raiders from the Catalan Dragons last season, says he fears for the Super League competition if the English success stories continue in the NRL — and he can’t blame the players for abandoning their home country. Raiders forward Elliott Whitehead scores a try. Picture: Gregg Porteous Source: News Corp Australia 
“It’s a big difference in wages for players,” Whitehead told foxsports.com.au . 
“Financially wise, your career only goes for 10-15 years tops, if you’re lucky. 
“You need to make your money as well as enjoy your sport. 
“I know they don’t get the sponsorships over there like the NRL does because of Premier League football and stuff.” 
Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW ! 
In terms of Englishmen in the competition, the NRL already boasts the likes of Whitehead, James Graham, Gareth Widdop, Josh Hodgson as well as Sam, George and Tom Burgess. Dan Sarginson and Jordan Turner have both come out this season, while Joe Greenwood is on his way after signing a three-year deal with the Gold Coast. St Helens forward Joe Greenwood is joining the Titans immediately. Source: Getty Images 
When asked which players had spoken to him about wanting to make the trip over, Whitehead said: “There’s a few, but I best not say their names otherwise their teams will be after them. 
“ ... I think a lot more want to come over and play in this competition. I don’t want to slag Super League off, but the NRL is the best competition in the world. 
“Week in, week out you’re up against tough opponents so I think there will be a lot of players want to come out and test themselves.” 
Whitehead arrived at the Raiders as a relative unknown, but proved to be one of the buys of the season in 2016. 
He featured in every game for the Green Machine, missing just two minutes of game time all season. 
The 27-year-old believes there are a host of other Englishmen who could make a similar impact. 
“There’s a lot of players who I reckon could come out and do the job as well, people like Kallum Watkins at Leeds, (Castleford’s) Luke Gale and (Wigan’s) John Bateman,” Whitehead said. 
“They’re the types of players I reckon who could come over and do a great job.”
